dublinCore.dc:title: 118 HR 2575 IH: Restaurant Revitalization Tax Credit Act
dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.

action.action-desc: Mr. Blumenauer (for himself and Mr. Phillips) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Ways and Means

form.official-title: To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to provide a partially refundable credit against payroll taxes for certain restaurants affected by the COVID–19 pandemic.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Restaurant Revitalization Tax Credit Act.

subsection.text: Subchapter D of chapter 21 of subtitle C of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by adding at the end the following new section:

In the case of an eligible employer, there shall be allowed as a credit against applicable employment taxes for each calendar quarter an amount equal to 100 percent of the wages with respect to each employee of such employer for such calendar quarter.

paragraph.text: The aggregate amount of wages which may be taken into account under subsection (a) by the eligible employer for any calendar quarter shall not exceed $25,000.

The credit allowed by subsection (a) with respect to any calendar quarter shall not exceed the applicable employment taxes (reduced by any credits allowed under subsections (e) and (f) of section 3111) on the wages paid with respect to the employment of all the employees of the eligible employer for such calendar quarter. For purposes of the preceding sentence, the credit allowed under subsection (a) shall be applied first against applicable employment taxes described in subsection (c)(1)(A).

subparagraph.text: If the amount of the credit under subsection (a) exceeds the limitation of paragraph (2), so much of such excess as does not exceed the applicable employer refund limitation shall be treated as an overpayment that shall be refunded under sections 6402(a) and 6413(b).
For purposes of subparagraph (A), the applicable employer refund limitation is the excess of—

clause.text: the amount of credit treated as an overpayment of the eligible employer by reason of this paragraph for all preceding calendar quarters.

subparagraph.header: Reduction based on number of employees
subparagraph.text: In the case of any eligible employer for which the average number of full-time employees (within the meaning of section 4980H) employed by such eligible employer during the last calendar quarter of 2022 (rounded to the nearest multiple of 1) exceeds 10, the $25,000 dollar amount under subparagraph (A)(ii)(I) shall be reduced (but not below zero) by the product of such excess and $2,500.

paragraph.text: The term applicable employment taxes means the following:

subparagraph.text: The term eligible employer means any employer—

clause.text: which is an eligible entity (as defined in section 5003(a) of the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021) which—

subclause.text: submitted an application for a grant under section 5003(c) of such Act in accordance with the procedures established by the Administrator of the Small Business Administration under such section,
certifies to the Secretary (in such form and manner as the Secretary requires) that such employer was eligible for a grant under such section, and
did not receive any grant funds under such section due to a lack of funding,

clause.text: which paid applicable employment taxes with respect to pay periods occurring in at least 2 calendar quarters of calendar year 2021, and
which meets the gross receipts test of subparagraph (B).

subparagraph.text: An employer meets the gross receipts test of this subparagraph if—

clause.text: the gross receipts of such employer for any applicable calendar year were less than 50 percent the gross receipts of such employer for calendar year 2019, or
the average gross receipts of such employer for all applicable calendar years were less than 70 percent the gross receipts of such employer for the calendar year 2019.

subparagraph.text: For purposes of this paragraph, the term applicable calendar year means any of the following:

subparagraph.header: Special rule for employers not in existence for entirety of 2019
subparagraph.text: In the case of any employer that was in existence before January 1, 2020, but not in existence on January 1, 2019, the amount of gross receipts taken into account for any applicable calendar year shall be the amount of such gross receipts (determined without regard to this clause) multiplied by the ratio of—

clause.text: the number of days during 2019 during which such employer was in existence, to

subparagraph.header: Special rule for employers not in existence before 2020
subparagraph.text: In the case of any employer that was not in existence before January 1, 2020, in applying this paragraph—

clause.text: the amount of gross receipts for calendar year 2019 shall be equal to the product of—

subclause.text: the amount of gross receipts for the period beginning on the date the employer was established and ending before March 14, 2020, and
the ratio of 366 to the number of days in the period described in subclause (I), and

clause.text: the amount of gross receipts for calendar year 2020 shall be equal to the product of—

subclause.text: the amount of gross receipts for the period beginning after March 13, 2020, and ending on December 31, 2020, and
the ratio of 366 to the number of days in the period described in subclause (I).

subparagraph.text: The term wages has the meaning given such term under section 3121(a), determined without regard to paragraph (1) thereof.
Such term shall not include any wages taken into account under sections 41, 45A, 45P, 45S, 51, and 1396.

paragraph.text: Any term used in this section which is also used in this chapter shall have the same meaning as when used in this chapter.

subsection.text: All persons treated as a single employer under subsection (a) or (b) of section 52, or subsection (m) or (o) of section 414, shall be treated as one employer for purposes of this section.

subsection.header: Election To not take certain wages into account
subsection.text: This section shall not apply to so much of the wages paid by an eligible employer as such employer elects (at such time and in such manner as the Secretary may prescribe) to not take into account for purposes of this section.
Any credit allowed under this section shall be treated as a credit described in section 3511(d)(2).

The Secretary shall waive any penalty under section 6656 for any failure to make a deposit of any applicable employment taxes if the Secretary determines that such failure was due to the reasonable anticipation of the credit allowed under this section.

Notwithstanding section 6501, the limitation on the time period for the assessment of any amount attributable to a credit claimed under this section shall not expire before the date that is 5 years after the later of—

paragraph.text: the date on which the original return which includes the calendar quarter with respect to which such credit is determined is filed, or
the date on which such return is treated as filed under section 6501(b)(2).

subsection.text: The Secretary shall issue such forms, instructions, regulations, and other guidance as are necessary—

paragraph.text: with respect to the application of the credit under subsection (a) to third party payors (including professional employer organizations, certified professional employer organizations, or agents under section 3504), including regulations or guidance allowing such payors to submit documentation necessary to substantiate the eligible employer status of employers that use such payors, and
to prevent the avoidance of the purposes of the limitations under this section, including through the leaseback of employees.

subsection.continuation-text: Any forms, instructions, regulations, or other guidance described in paragraph (1) shall require the customer to be responsible for the accounting of the credit and for any liability for improperly claimed credits and shall require the certified professional employer organization or other third party payor to accurately report such tax credits based on the information provided by the customer.

subsection.text: This section shall only apply to wages paid after December 31, 2022, and before January 1, 2024.
Paragraph (2) of section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code, is amended by inserting “3135,” after “3134”.
The table of sections for subchapter D of chapter 21 of subtitle C of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by adding at the end the following:

The Administrator of the Small Business Administration shall coordinate with and provide information to the Secretary of the Treasury (or the Secretary's delegate) to assist in identifying employers that are eligible for the credit allowed by section 3135 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as added by this section.
The amendments made by this section shall apply to calendar quarters beginning after December 31, 2022.
